Authors:
Elene R Valdivia, Kate L Hertweck, Sung Ki Cho, John C
Walker
Title: DVL RTFL
Keywords:
DEVIL (DVL)/ROT-FOUR-LIKE (RTFL), Plant Development,
Peptides, Arabidopsis thaliana
Abstract:
The DEVIL (DVL) or ROT-FOUR-LIKE (RTFL) family of small
proteins was discovered during activation-tagging screens in
Arabidopsis. Overexpression of several of these genes results in similar
pleiotropic phenotypes: shortened rosette leaves and floral organs,
altered silique development, and stalks at the base of pedicels and
trichomes. Silenced lines or insertional mutants have no noticeable
phenotype. More than 20 DVL/RTFL genes have been identified in
Arabidopsis. The corresponding proteins (40-144 amino acids) share a
highly conserved region of 30 amino acids located close to the C
terminus, which is sufficient for their function. The overexpression
phenotypes might be explained by alterations in polarized cellular
proliferation. The mechanism of action of these small proteins is
currently unknown. They appear to be localized to the plasma membrane
where they might interact with a receptor. DVL/RTFL overexpression
alters a large number of genes involved in signaling pathways,
particularly in hormonal responses.
